What is Verus Vault, and how does it protect funds on a VerusID, including from private key theft, and what are some additional features and benefits of using Verus Vault?

Verus Vault is a feature that allows you to protect funds on a VerusID, even if your private key is stolen. When you lock your VerusID with Vault, you cannot spend funds from that identity until it is unlocked again. However, you can still receive funds and stake those same funds on the Verus network to earn rewards.

To use Verus Vault, you need to have at least one primary identity and one revocation/recovery ID configured. A locked VerusID can always be revoked and recovered by its revocation and recovery authority identities, which can circumvent the lock. This means that if someone tries to unlock your identity without authorization, the revocation and recovery authority can detect this and recover the funds.

One of the key benefits of Verus Vault is that it provides a decentralized solution to the "5 dollar wrench attack", where an attacker steals your private key by physical means. With Verus Vault, you can set a delay between the time someone tries to unlock your identity and the time when they can actually access the funds. This delay can be set to any length of time, providing an additional layer of security.

In addition to protecting funds, Verus Vault also provides security for your IDs and NFTs, as well as time locks for other purposes such as vesting schedules, trusts, and inheritance. This means that you can use Verus Vault to protect and recover not only your funds but also your digital assets and legacy.

Overall, Verus Vault offers a new level of blockchain protection and decentralized funds recovery, allowing you to preserve your assets and generational blockchain wealth without relying on traditional banking institutions.
